Classifications: The Flies Instead of Nails on Christ's Heart
Variation Example: Flies look like nails & prevent more nails being driven in.

Classifications: Contest of Creation between God & the Devil
Variation Example: This misc. type comprises different tales dealing with the theme, “God & the devil as creators”. They have a strong dualistic tendency. Examples: (1) The creation of contrasting animals. The devil makes crea-tures in competition with God (often copies the creatures God made). (2) The devil tries to create humans but fails, & instead he creates certain animals. For example, God makes Adam out of clay & the devil tries to copy him. He shapes the clay & blows life into it, but it turns into a mon-key. In other variants, the devil makes inferior races of humans. (3) The good principle competes with the bad one, as God & the devil create various animals. God creates a wolf which is called “God’s dog”, & the destructive devil deliberately creates goats. The devil’s animals devour God’s animals. (4) The devil’s animals are brought to life by God. The devil shapes some animals but only God (the name of God) can bring them to life. When the devil refuses to utter God’s name, the animals remain lifeless. (5) God takes the devil’s animals. The devil creates (owns) animals that God wants for himself. God alters the appearance (colors) of the devil’s animals so that he cannot recognize them.

Classifications: God & Devil Dispute over Miser's Soul
Variation Example: God says the devil may have the soul of a miser if he can fill a cask with money. God knocks the bottom out of the cask & hangs it in a tree over a gorge. The devil is unable to fill the cask & leaves the soul to God.
This misc. type consists of various jests about Christ & St. Peter during their visit on earth or creating the world.

Classifications: St. Peter Wants to Create a Man
Variation Example: (replaces the head of an innocent, beheaded person). He puts the head on backwards. St. Peter consoles himself with the idea that the resuscitated person could become a rope-maker who has to walk backwards while working. In some variants Christ asks St. Peter to settle a dispute between a woman & the devil. Thoughtlessly he cuts off the heads of both. When he puts the heads back, he exchanges them. Since that time it is said that women have had the devil inside their bodies.

Classifications: St. Peter Cannot Sell His Donkey
Variation Example: St. Peter Cannot Sell His Donkey because he points out all its defects.

Christ & St. Peter find a horseshoe. St. Peter is unwilling to lean over to pick it up. Christ picks it up, sells it & buys cherries with the proceeds. He drops them one by one on the way & the thirsty St. Peter has to bend over to pick up every single cherry.

Classifications: St. Peter Acts as God for a Day
Variation Example: A girl takes her goat (cow, pig, goose) to pasture & leaves it, saying, “May God take care of you!” There-upon St. Peter, who is taking God’s place, has to run everywhere after the goat.

Classifications: St. Peter Gets Permission to Gather Grapes
Variation Example: St. Peter returns to heaven late & says that in prosperity men forget to pray. Thereupon God sends rising prices to earth. This time St. Peter returns to heaven quickly & says that now all the people pray & ask for God’s help.

St. Peter, against Christ’s advice, insists on going into a pub where carpenters, soldiers & Gypsies are celebrating. Christ puts a violin on his back & when St. Peter explains to the people that he cannot play the instrument, they beat (laugh at) him.
St. Peter, angry at carpenters, wants Christ to make wood (trees) with iron knots (branches, nails). But Christ makes the branches only out of hard wood.

St. Peter receives two (three) cakes from a farmwife (bakery woman). He shares only one (bad) cake with Christ & hides the other (good) one under his cap where it burns all his hair off. In some variants St. Peter becomes so tousled during a fight in a pub that he loses all his hair.

St. Peter becomes angry at Christ for destroying the harvest of all the farmers because of only one sinner. But he himself drowns a whole hive because of one bee sting. When Christ points to the parallel, St. Peter is subdued. Or, St. Peter protests when a ship is sunk by Christ because one sinner is aboard. Christ sends him to fetch honey from a hive. St. Peter crushes all the bees when one stings him.
St. Peter receives a cake (pancake, bread) from a woman & eats it secretly. When Christ talks to St. Peter he tries to hide what he is eating & spits it out. Afterwards mushrooms grow from the cake.
Christ keeps asking questions of the gluttonous St. Peter so that he must continually spit out mouthfuls in order to be able to answer.

St. Peter (man) doubts the justice of the cre-ation & complains that large trees have small fruit. Thereupon Christ (God) lets gourds (melons) grow on small branches & nuts (walnuts, acorns, pears, figs) on strong trees. When an acorn falls on St. Peter’s head, he understands the order of the natural phenomena

Phrygian farmers take an old man (Silen) to Midas (to a nameless poor man), who recognizes him as the educator of Dionysos. Midas organizes a feast for the old man & then hands him over to Dionysos. The grateful Dionysos gives Midas a wish. He wishes that everything he touches will turn to gold. Even his food & drink turn to gold so that he cannot eat. He asks Dionysos to take back the gift. Dionysos agrees & Midas has to bathe in the river Paktolos. From that time on the river contains gold. In some variants Midas dies from hunger & thirst.

Christ carries the cross to Golgotha. When he wants to rest for a moment, a Jew (shoemaker), who owns the house there, does not permit it. From then on the Jew has to wander about on earth forever, unable to die.

A captain (Dutchman) is unable to sail around a cape (reach a harbor) because of a strong wind. He swears that he will reach his goal, even if it takes forever. (He is condemned to sail forever because of his sins.) Ordinary sailors who encounter this ship believe it to be a ghost ship (they see it in different forms). Often its crew give them letters addressed to people who died long ago. Meeting the Flying Dutchman portends storm, shipwreck, or death.

A sailor (farmer, Gypsy) in distress at sea (in a difficult situation) promises to sacrifice a giant candle (as high as a mast, as long as a pole) more expensive than he can afford. When he is asked to produce it, he replies that the candle would become smaller by itself, or he discharges his promise by offering a small light, or does not fulfill the promise at all. Version from the Middle Ages: A farmer leading a cow & a calf to St. Michael fears the sea & calls on the saint for help, promising to sacrifice the calf. When free from danger, he says that St. Michael was foolish to expect him to give the calf. Again the sea rises, again the farmer calls for help, & St. Michael appears. Now the farmer promises to sacrifice both the cow & the calf, but again he does not discharge his promise. The third time the sea swallows him up together with the animals.

A pious man (old woman) lights a candle for (before the image of) God (a saint), & another one for (before the image of) the devil. When a priest (sexton) asks him why he does this, he explains that one never knows where one will end up. So it is wise to be on good terms with both.

This misc. type comprises various tales dealing with divine rewards & punishments from God (Christ, St. Peter) for mothers, fathers, children, orphans, poor persons, emperors, kings, queens, robbers, etc. for piety, generosity, toler ance, birth, crime, blasphemy, laziness.

On Christmas Eve, outside a church, a farmer of (the fictitious town) Kolbeck holds a dance with fifteen other farmers & three women, while a mass is said. When the priest comes out of the church, he curses all the dancers in God’s name. From then on they have to dance ceaselessly. They dance themselves into the earth, hollowing out a hole, & finally die. After their death, as many stones as there were dancers were set up as a memorial.

This tale exists chiefly in two different forms: (1) A woman (man) who thinks she has overslept for an early church service (during Advent, on Christmas or New Year’s) hurries to church. She finds it brightly lit & filled with unfamiliar worshipers – it is the Mass of the Dead. A dead acquaintance (neighbor) tells her to leave. Terrified, she runs away, but leaves a piece of clothing behind. She goes back but cannot retrieve it because the church door will not open. The next morning, the clothing is found, ripped to shreds, in the graveyard. In some variants, the witness becomes ill & dies shortly after. (2) A person accidentally witnesses a Mass of the Dead (during Advent, on Christmas or New Year’s, on All Saint’s Day, All Souls Day, or the day of a particular saint). A priest asks him if he will re ceive (serve) Holy Communion. The man agrees & is blessed. The priest tells him that he had been unable to rest in peace until he could administer this sacrament to a living person. The visitor dies shortly after.
A woman uses bread (corn, grain) to clean her child. As punishment Christ (God, Virgin Mary, saint) shortens the grain to the length it has today.

A poor mistreated orphan leaves her foster-parents & reaches a dark forest. After she gives all her belongings to four other children, suddenly a beautiful woman comes down from heaven & takes the fourth child. The woman is grateful & promises all heaven’s blessings to the orphan girl. When she waves to the stars, silver coins fall down into her outstretched shirt.

This misc. type comprises various religious legends dealing with offences against the commandment to rest on Sunday (another holy day) by people who work in the house or fields, go hunting, or participate in forbidden amusements. Punish-ments for these offences are various. Examples: Hay harvested on Sunday turns to stone. Someone who goes picking berries instead of going to church becomes ill (dies, is lost). Someone who goes hunting instead of to church suffers an accident (dies). Someone who plays bowls on Sunday is killed by a ball. A choirboy who plays cards behind the organ is caught by the devil.People who play cards or dance on Christmas instead of going to church sink into the earth along with the house in which they met.

A brother (sister) kills his (her) brother (sister) & buries him (her) in the earth. From the bones a shepherd makes an instrument (harp, violin, flute) which brings the secret to light. Or the murder is revealed by a (speaking) tree growing from the grave.

A stepmother buries a girl alive under a tree (kills her daughter). Her hair grows as wheat or as a bush & sings about her misfortunes. Thus she is discovered & rescued. The stepmother is buried in the same hole.
A murderer buys a calf’s (sheep’s) head. On his way home blood drops out of the head. When the officials find him, the calf’s head turns into the head of the man whom he had murdered.

Classifications: The Princess Who Murdered Her Child
Variation Example: A queen (princess, step-mother, father) kills her child. A young man learns bird language. A bird (dove) sings, “The bones lie under the tree”. (The dead child is found, the murderer killed).

Midas (a nameless emperor), disgusted with his riches, has retired to the forest. Without being asked he intervenes in the judgment of a musical challenge between Pan & Apollo in favor of Pan. As punishment Apollo gives him donkey’s ears (horse’s, sheep’s or goat’s ears). Midas hides them under a crown. His barber (cossack, his foster-brother) cannot keep the secret, so he digs a hole, whispers the secret into it, & covers the hole up again. But a reed growing there (a musical instrument made from the reed) gives the secret away.

While traveling on earth God (Christ, St. Peter, Nicholas) asks his com-panion (soldier, beggar, craftsman, clergyman, St. Peter) to prepare a lamb (goat, cow, chicken). The companion secretly eats the lamb’s heart (liver, kidney, brain, tongue) & denies having done so. He explains that this sort of animal had no heart. When God shows his might by various miracles (resuscitation, healing), the man still does not tell him the truth, but instead tries to imitate God. He fails & is condemned to death. God offers his help, but the deceiver prefers to die rather than to yield. Neverthe less God rescues him. Later God divides a treasure into three parts. The third part is to go to the one who ate the heart, whereupon the companion confesses that it was he who ate it.

A servant (cook, St. Peter) is asked by his master (Christ) to prepare a goose (crane, chicken). The servant eats one leg & maintains that the goose had only one leg (all cranes generally have only one leg). He enforces his point by showing geese who stand on one leg. The master refutes his servant’s assertion by shooting away the geese so that they use both legs. The servant replies that if he had frightened the roasted goose in the same way, it would have showed its second leg as well

Classifications: The Man Who Was Burned Up & Lived Again
Variation Example: A man (hermit, saint, angel) has committed a sin & is burned (is told by an angel to burn himself). A part of his body (heart) is carried away by Christ (God, twelve apostles, St. Peter, beggar, monk, girl, mother of the dead man), & from contact with it a woman conceives & bears a child. Or, a hunter finds the hermit’s heart in the ashes & takes it home, telling his daughter to prepare it for him. The daughter (his sister, girl) instead eats it herself & becomes pregnant from it. The newborn child can walk, talk, prophesy, can do magic things & has supernatural powers. It is the reborn hero (hermit)

Classifications: St. George Teaches the Poor Man
Variation Example: “Whoever steals a little & lies a little will become rich.” Russian variant: St. George teaches a poor man (Nesterka, Gypsy) how to become rich: one has to steal & to lie. Thereupon the poor man steals a golden stirrup (saddle, goblet) from him & denies the theft.

A host gives shelter to St. Peter & Christ, who must sleep in the same bed. In the night the (drunken) host beats St. Peter (for various reasons). St. Peter changes places with Christ. The host then comes to beat the other lodger, & St. Peter again suffers the blows.

Classifications: Woman Created from a Monkey's Tail
Variation Example: When God intends to create Eve from Adam’s rib a monkey (devil, dog, cat, fox) steals it. God pursues the monkey (sends an angel to catch it) & catches its tail. The tail tears off, God holds it in his hand & creates Eve from the monkey’s tail (devil’s, dog’s, cat’s, fox’s tail).
In God’s absence, St. Peter lets an unworthy tailor into heaven. The tailor throws God’s foot-stool at an old woman thief on earth. He is expelled from heaven.

A self-righteous shoemaker (driver, rich man) who is never satisfied, criticizes his journeymen, his servants, & his wife. He dreams he is dead. Before he is admitted to heaven, St. Peter warns him against fault-finding Despite his good intentions he continues to complain. He criticizes angels who carry a beam crosswise, & other angels who carry water in a sieve or pull a wagon with two horses harnessed in front & behind. Finally the faultfinder is expelled from heaven. When he awakes from his dream, he continues to criticize the things he had seen there, showing that his character did not change.
